item.title: Caesar Cipher
item.description: A type of substitution cipher that shifts the alphabet by 3 places. Example: Fade becomes IDGH

item.title: Historical Cryptography
item.description: Egypt 1900 BC Hieroglyphics Assyria 1500BC Cuneiform Spartan Scytale Transposition Cipher by writing message on parchment wrapped around a rod 1518 Johannes Trithemus wrote the first book on cyrptography Vigenere Cipher Sir Francis Bacon Thomas Jefferson Wheel Cipher Led to development of M209 Grippenstierna Machine in Sweden William Friedman Coined the phrase “Cryptanalysis” Established school for cryptanalysis Later moved to Maryland and began the cryptanalysis capability that grew into the NSA

item.title: Kerckhoff's Principle
Lucifer Cipher
item.description: Developed in 1976 by Horst Feistel of IBM Modified by NSA to become the US Data Encryption Standard (DES) Thought to resist attacks for 20 years into the future

item.title: Moore's Law
item.description: The number of transistors on a chip will double every 18 months, and the price will halve.

item.title: New Directions
item.description: “New Directions in Cryptography” was a paper published in 1976 by Whitfield Diffie and Martin Hellman that proposed two mathematically related crypto variables, called “Keys”.

item.title: Substitution Cipher
item.description: A cipher that involves replacing one value for another. See also: Transposition Cipher

item.title: The Enigma
item.description: Initially designed as a civilian cipher to protect trade secrets Used by Germany in WW2 Example of an excellent system deployed imperfectly See also: The Purple Machine

item.title: The Purple Machine
item.description: The US codename for the WW2 Japanese Foreign Office cryptosystem used for diplomatic communications Used before and during WW2 Electromechanical stepping-switch using 6x25 substitution table

item.title: Transposition Cipher
item.description: A type of cipher that rearranges the order of the letters. Example: Fade becomes DFEA (with a key of 3412)
